Message.Title: "Rumor: Alibaba to Release Internet TV Set-Top Box"
Message.Msg: From Marbridge Daily: "According to an industry source, Chinese e-commerce conglomerate Alibaba Group's Alibaba Cloud Computing ("AliCloud") subsidiary plans to release an internet TV set-top box (STB), called "AliBox" (unofficial translation), allowing multi-screen interaction and online shopping through users' TV sets. Alibaba is said to have begun R&D on the STB in the last half of 2012, and will possibly work with Hangzhou-based DTV and IPTV operator Wasu Digital TV or Hunan province TV media operator Hunan Broadcasting System (HBS) to release the product in the near future."

Topic.Title: Hyper local targeting is in 2013 the biggest win in mobile and Local Corp is the Market-Leader in Hyper-Local

Message.Msg: Key Takeaways from Q1’13 of Local Corp: . • Sequential revenue growth from $20.9 million in Q4 to $21.8 million in Q1, up 4% • Margin expansion drove positive cash flow from operations one quarter ahead of schedule • Record traffic: » Overall traffic on the site and network was a record 106 million monthly unique visitors (MUV) » Organic traffic on the site was a record 49 million MUVs » Mobile traffic was 32 million MUVS for the first quarter 2013 • Costs savings due to cessation of direct sales efforts during 1Q • Made significant progress on key objectives for the year: » Expand gross margins on our largest revenue stream (O&O) – total gross margin up 4 points » Expand revenue of our highest gross margin business (Network) – Network ex TAC up 67% from prior year quarter • Reiterating prior guidance: » Revenue between $93 million and $95 million » Adjusted EBITDA of at least $5 million •Completed a $5 million convertible note financing in April 2013 Less

Topic.Title: apology to yang?

Topic.Title: apology to yang?

Message.Msg: Totally agree. His $1 billion investment in Alibaba has to be one of the deals of the century. We just heard from the new CFO that he considers that their recent sale of 1/2 of their original holding was a mistake. It wasn't long ago that the pundits were letting Jack Ma and his cohorts say all kinds of critical things about YHOO. He was just trying to pressure them to sell and with the help of the press, he was successful...the same folks who ran off Yang. Everyone knew the value of Alibaba and that it was going to grow. It is why Yang didn't want to sell for $32 to Msoft. He was right. But there was too much impatience from wall street to "monetize". The 40% would be worth $40 billion pre tax at IPO according to several analysts. I wonder if Loeb was a proponent of the sale.

Topic.Title: apology to yang?

Message.Msg: 1. Alibaba Group has ZERO bearing on MSFT buying Yahoo as Jack Ma had right of 1st refusal to buyback its stake. Yang just thought revenue would grow to $10B in 2010/2011 and $12B by now. Him and everyone else vastly overvalued the core. Look up the 2008' Investor Day on Scribd and you'll laugh your #$%$ off looking at the Powerpoint slides. 2. Yahoo HAD to sell part of its stake in Alibaba Group as Ma GUARANTEED he wouldn't IPO until they did. He didn't need the money, made a deal with Silver Lake for employee's so had no need to IPO AG. They've been rumored for YEARS and its only gained traction in the last 6mos. cause Yahoo cashed in part of its chips and will cash in another chunk at IPO. Mistake? maybe but they also bought 200,000,000 shares with that money which equates today's share price to around $21. They can always hold that final stake but at some point a company has to move on.

Topic.Title: apology to yang?

Message.Msg: I had forgotten about the right of first refusal and stand corrected. But producing the cash he would have needed to exercise (in 2008) may be a different story. In any case, him "guaranteeing" anything as he did was most likely posturing to get his way, IMHO. No secret he wanted rid of yahoo sooner than later. They have been enjoying good mailbox money along the way, enjoying the ride. CFO Goldman's comment was the first I had ever heard anyone mention regret at selling and it portends that it is not for sure they will sell at IPO. It will be interesting to see what they do about last piece.

Topic.Title: ICAHN

Message.Msg: lol okay but keep it a secret... (~~, I do think their is one I bought today. Here is an excerpt from a good article on why initiated a positioin & a little bit on his strategy. "Loeb's Third Point hedge fund has built up a $1.1 billion stake in Sony, making it the Japanese group's biggest shareholder, and Loeb said on Tuesday he was pushing Sony to sell up to a fifth of its profitable music and movie business in a move he says would help turn around its struggling electronics business. "I rely a lot on my experience and pattern recognition. The Sony situation reminded me a lot of Yahoo," Loeb said in an interview with Reuters in Tokyo on Wednesday." Will try to post link below - sometimes it no work for me... http://finance.yahoo.com/news/u-hedge-fund-calls-sony-033231510.html BTW, I bought YHOO for the first time just before Loeb began his campaign - right after they canned Bartz & it was in the 13$ range. It traded as high as the 17$ range fairly quickly - I believe Loeb was accumulating heavily at that time - but I didn't know that then. I stayed in based on some great information from Eric Jackson's articles - which were plentiful at that time. So I do owe a debt to him because he went against the grain on alot of his thinking & he was spot on most of the time.

Topic.Title: ICAHN

Message.Msg: Since you seem to be researching right now, there is another great article just out from Dealbook/ NYT I can't post Dealbook links so here is an excerpt - but you should look it up - if only to be reminded of the letters Loeb likes to send. First thing I thought of this morning reading the Reuters article was it was a darn shame we are not likely to see a terse letter - Poiliteness & Respect are the Japanese way. Too bad! (~~, Before Sony, Mr. Loeb’s biggest target was Yahoo, where he waged a war to oust Scott Thompson as chief executive. Soon after winning that fight, Mr. Loeb successfully poached Marissa Mayer from Google to serve as the embattled Web pioneer’s new leader. Since the investor first began agitating at Yahoo, the company’s shares have soared 81 percent. “You can see Dan’s fingerprints all over the turnaround,” said Eric Jackson, a fellow hedge fund manager and Yahoo investor. “He’s brought an assurance to other Wall Street investors that there’s an owner in the boardroom. That’s what this company needed...” "...“We think Mr. Loeb’s bold proposal bears consideration,” analysts at Macquarie wrote in a research note on Tuesday, agreeing that a spinoff of the entertainment unit could propel Sony’s stock by 60 percent. “We recognize this latent value may indeed exist.”
